item.title: Tomato Sauce
item.description:
This is a recipe for a general purpose tomato sauce that can be used for pasta dishes, as a base for other sauces, a dipping sauce or any practical application you would find for a tomato sauce!

Ingredients

  • 1/2 cup of Extra Virgin Olive Oil
  • 2x Cans of Tomatoes
  • Basil (Fresh preferred but dried is fine.)
  • Garlic (Fresh preferred. Powder, salt or “easy” garlic is fine.)

Directions

  1. Peel and crush garlic.
  2. Pour the oil into a pan or pot and bring to a medium heat.
  3. Add garlic to the pan and fry until the garlic starts to brown.
  4. Remove the garlic from the pan.
  5. Tip the pot to one side and add the canned tomatoes to the top such that the tomatoes and their juices will roll into the oil.
  6. Stir occasionally to prevent burning while bringing it to the boil.
  7. Keep stirring to prevent burning.
  8. Add basil.
  9. Remove from the heat and allow to cool.
  10. You may now store the sauce or use it.

Notes:

  • You can add tomato puree to the sauce whilst boiling to thicken.
  • (Optional) After cooling, you can leave the sauce covered with a towel to ferment over night before storage.

item.title: Cranmeode - Cranberry Mead
item.description:
This is a recipe for making Cranmeode or cranberry mead if you prefer. It has a sweet taste and fizzy finish.

Ingredients

  • 4 litres of Water
  • 1kg honey ( You can replace 500g of honey with brown sugar )
  • 300g Cranberries
  • Yeast
  • Raisins (Optional) (Recommended)

Directions

  1. Activate your yeast in warm water.
  2. Add honey to a 5 litre pot or bucket.
  3. Boil 4 litres of water and add to the pot.
  4. Mix the honey and boiling water until it is one fluid.
  5. Add the cranberries.
  6. Allow to simmer for about 20 minutes.
  7. Add water as needed / wanted.
  8. Set the pot aside and allow to cool.
  9. Once the mixture is blood temperature or lower add the yeast and mix together.
  10. Observe for bubbles. Once bubbling starts, add a lid to the pot and cover with a towel or old t-shirt.
  11. Wait 24 hours.
  12. You can now begin bottling the mead.
  13. Once bottled, add some raisins to the fluid with one teaspoon of sugar per litre.
  14. Store in your fridge for 3-5 days, release gas from the bottles in the morning and at night.

Notes

  1. This recipe is proportional, if you want a smaller batch, adjust each ingredient by the same fraction.
  2. The raisins are used for measuring the state of the mead. The more of them that float the closer it is to being done.
    • Note that it is possible that not all of them will float by the time the mead is finished.
  3. Try experimenting with adding fruits or heather.
  4. Adjust sugar / honey levels for sweetness / sourness, etc.

item.title: Sourdough Starter
item.description:
Sourdough bread requires a bit of maintenance unlike notmal white bread. You need to make a starter in advance and maintain it so that you can use it when needed. You can maintain these starters for years, once you have one going you can use it whenever you need. Just be sure not to deplete it or you’ll have to start again.

Ingredients

  • Plain or bread flour.
  • Sugar (optional)
  • Water

Directions

  1. Add one teaspoon of sugar to a jar.
  2. Add three heaped tablespoons of flour to the jar.
  3. Add enough water to cover.
  4. Mix this together.
  5. Loosely cover the jar with a towel, do not put the lid on.
  6. The next day it should have a smell to it now and some bubbles, feed it with two heaped tablespoons of flour to the jar and enough water to cover. Mix it.
  7. For the next few days repeat the above feeding process.
  8. After five days your starter should be ready for use.
  9. You can now store and use as needed. Remember to feed it before use and to feed it occasionally (every dau is not required at this point) to keep it alive.

Notes

  • It’s good to experiment with sourdough starters and see what works for you.
    • The recipe on based.cooking has some good tips and advice.
  • Make sure not to feed it with sugar and to only use sugar on the first day.
    • Sugar is not a necessary step but I find it works for me.

item.title: Sima - Finnish Lemon Mead
item.description:
This is a recipe for making Sima, which is a Finnish lemon drink. I learned it from my Finnish flatmate at uni so it is 100% trad approved. This method is technically a “minute” mead. Meaning that it can be made quickly and cheaply. This is not a traditional mead recipe but it is a cheaper and easier alternative that is great for beginners to try out before buying expensive ingredients to try for the first time.

Ingredients

  • 8 litres of Water
  • 4 Lemons
  • 500g Brown sugar
  • 500g honey
  • Yeast
  • Raisins (Optional) (Recommended)

Directions

  1. Activate your yeast in warm water.
  2. Wash and zest and juice lemons.
  3. Add lemon zest, sugar and honey to a 10 litre pot or bucket.
  4. Boil 4 litres of water and add to the sugar mixture.
  5. Mix the sugar mixture and boiling water until it is one fluid.
  6. Add the remainder of the water.
  7. Add the lemon juice.
  8. Continue mixing and wait for the fluid to reach blood temperature.
  9. Add yeast. Observe for bubbles. Once bubbling starts, add a lid to the pot and cover with a towel or old t-shirt.
  10. Wait 24 hours.
  11. You can now begin bottling the mead.
  12. Once bottled, add some raisins to the fluid with one teaspoon of sugar per litre.
  13. Store in your fridge for 3-5 days, release gas from the bottles in the morning and at night.

Notes

  1. This recipe is proportional, if you want a smaller batch, adjust each ingredient by the same fraction.
  2. For this recipe I use two 5 litre pots instead of a single pot or bucket.
  3. The raisins are used for measuring the state of the mead. The more of them that float the closer it is to being done.
    • Note that it is possible that not all of them will float by the time the mead is finished.
  4. Try experimenting with adding fruits or heather.
  5. Adjust sugar levels for sweetness / sourness, etc.

item.title: Overnight Oats
item.description:
Overnight oats is a nice easy alternative to porridge that you eat cold instead. A very simple dish to make and can be supplemented with various additions to increase taste, macros and texture.

This is my personal way of making it, you will find hundreds of ways of doing it online though, experiment until you find what you like.

  • ‚è≤Ô∏è Prep time: 5 min
  • üçΩÔ∏è Servings: 1

Ingredients

  • Rolled Oats
  • Whole Milk
  • Whey Protein Powder
  • Greek Yoghurt (Optional)
  • Fruit of choice (Optional)

Directions

  1. Measure out your preferred serving of oats. Add to a glass or cup.
    • I like to go for a good couple of handfuls.
  2. Add one serving of whey protein powder to the oats.
  3. At this stage you can add other things you like to it. I sometimes add cinnamon or nutmeg.
  4. Pour milk until oats and whey are covered.
  5. Mix together until whey powder is evenly distributed.
  6. Add more milk as needed, you want to cover the dry ingredients entirely.
  7. Cover the glass or cup with cling film and place in the fridge.
  8. In the morning you will now have overnight oats.
    • Depending on how much milk you used you will now find either:
      • A peanut butter like consistency
      • A milkshake like consistency
      • Something in between.
    • Experimenting is key until you find the right consistency for you.
  9. You may now add Yoghurt to the top. (Optional)
  10. You may now add your fruit of choice to the yoghurt. (Optional)

Notes:

  1. You can use many different kinds of ingredients when making this. I plan to update this recipe when I find interesting additions and alternatives.
  2. I use a 100% whey protein powder, absent of soy, pea and other “proteins”.
  3. You can add whatever you like to this, the key with this is experimenting and finding what you like.
    • I like to switch whey flavours around, sometimes I add some chocolate, etc.

item.title: Steak Tartare
item.description:
This is an exact copy of my Steak Tartare recipe from based.cooking

Steak Tartare is a dish prepared using raw ground / minced beef and egg yolk. A popular dish in Europe, this recipe is a good stepping stone into the world of raw meats, organs and pates.

  • ‚è≤Ô∏è Prep time: 10 min
  • üçΩÔ∏è Servings: 4

Ingredients

  • Ground Beef (Lean as possible)
  • Eggs
  • Onion or Shallots
  • Capers
  • Gherkin / Cornichons
  • Parsley (Optional)
  • Ketchup (Optional)
  • Mustard (Optional)
  • Worcestershire Sauce (Optional)

Directions

  1. Dice your onions or shallots.
  2. Finely slice your cornichons.
  3. Rinse, drain and chop your capers.
  4. Chop parsley. (Optional)
  5. Chop ground beef into smaller pieces.
  6. Add the above to a mixing bowl and mix with hands.
  7. Add ketchup, mustard or Worcestershire sauce as needed and mix further. (Optional)
  8. Separate an egg yolk from the whites.
  9. Loosely roll some of the mixture into a ball in your hand and place onto a plate and press softly to form a bowl shape, add egg yolk to indentation.
  10. Serve, you may now add salt and pepper as desired.
